Power series centered at \(x_0\) 

A general power series has the form \[ b_0 + b_1(x-x_0) + b_2(x-x_0)^2 + \cdots = \sum_{p=0}^\infty b_p(x-x_0)^p\]

Exactly the same considerations apply to this general power series as apply to the ‘special’ series \(\sum_{p=0}^\infty b_p x^p\) except that the variable \(x\) is replaced by \((x-x_0).\) The radius of convergence of the general series is obtained in the same way: \[R = \lim_{p \to \infty} \left|\dfrac{b_p}{b_{p+1}}\right|\] and the interval of convergence is now shifted to have centre at \(x = x_0\) (see Figure below). The series is absolutely convergent if \(|x − x_0| < R\), diverges if \(|x − x_0| > R\) and may or may not converge if \(|x − x_0| = R\).
